ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: i learned how to read and critique fiction. professor choi taught us to read pieces analytically to see what strategies we could pull from the writer. i also learned to write fiction (never done that before!)
I developed a lot of critical reading skills, especially identifying and applying different creative writing techniques!

I got to practice critically reading and deconstructing popular and classic works of fiction. I also had a structured way to practice my short story writing and the techniques and structures that go into building a successful story.
We were able to formulate and work on different types of fiction, give and receive feedback in class, and learn from readings to be able to build our own craft.
I learned to take myself seriously as a writer

How to write and review my work, and also how to improve it based on others' feedback. The biggest insight was that there is still a very long way for me to go in the process of becoming a writer and I'm very grateful for that.
The ability to read short fiction and apply techniques of authors to your own work. Also the ability to write short stories or scenes with an understanding of the processes of craft and revision.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
strengths: professor's choi thoughtful and engaging discussions, the writing assignment and our feedback 
weaknesses: none

There were a lot of strengths: free writing time, group workshops, high engagement (especially over Zoom), deep discussions, and Prof. Choi is great! I especially think that the workshop style of the course was one of its greatest strengths, and really let me dig deeper and fully flesh out one of my pieces in much greater depth than I expected.

This course was fantastic. I appreciated the fact that every student had the chance to present a story, some of their work and their perspectives on the works that we read. I also appreciated building relationships with my classmates through small workshop breakout rooms. I also appreciated Professor Choi's commitment to the well-being of the students and her willingness to share about her own personal experiences in the industry!

The strength of this course is the class and the professor. The professor gave specific feedback on writing exercises each week, which was very helpful for improvement. The class discussions were also a high point, as each student got the chance to explain their perspective on the week's reading and analyse how the writing was effective. I also liked the lengthy focus at the end of the class on expanding and revising a single story, as we were able to produce a refined work.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: na. class was engaging, even virtually.

The moments of discussion in the course were really helpful and enjoyable. I would have appreciated having the chance to do more in-class writing exercises but I also recognize that the time constraint is a bit of a challenge!

For the most part, I think that this course succeeded in its virtual seminar format. Occasionally, discussions might have flowed a bit better and it would have been nice to get to know the students in the class, especially as the workshop format is more personal. However, I really enjoyed taking this class, even on Zoom.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: definitely, if they want to learn how to write fiction. this course led me to think more expansively and to more confidently present my writing in class.

Yes absolutely! Even if you don't have any creative writing experience, this class is so fun and accessible, plus you come out of it with a couple pieces done and ready to be looked over and written out more if you want.

Absolutely! This class is a great introduction to creative writing at Yale. It is very low pressure and is a friendly environment where you can grow in your craft and relationship with other students.
yes, especially if in-person
yesssss

I would definitely recommend this course to another student passionate about creative writing but unsure of what role creative writing will play in their life down the road. It helped me gain confidence in my writing abilities and was a great way to keep myself motivated and write stories throughout the semester. Each week, we received a new prompt and had a new opportunity to create a world through fiction. The readings were super interesting, and you'll meet incredible writers dedicated to improving their work.

I would recommend this course. The professor was great, the readings were inspiring, and the exercises each week were a rigorous way to improve writing over the course of the semester. The final workshops on a single story were valuable opportunities for reader feedback and resulted in the completion of a final work.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: zoom seminar (mandatory attendance)
N/A
